title: China sales surge puts Jaguar Land Rover back in black
text:
Jaguar Land Rover has returned to profit after it was boosted by a sales surge in China.

The Coventry-based firm reported a profit of £156million for the three months to September 30, compared to a £90million loss in the same period a year ago.

This was after revenues rose by 8 per cent to £6.1billion, helped by 'sharply' improved sales in China.

China boost: Jaguar Land Rover reported a profit of £156m for the three months to September 30, compared to a £90m loss in the same period a year ago

JLR, which is owned by India's Tata Group, has faced tough conditions lately due to the US-China trade war and a backlash against polluting diesel cars.

It racked up a record £3.6billion loss last year. Earlier this year it announced it was axing 4,500 jobs from its 40,000-strong workforce.

But Sir Ralph Speth, the company's boss, said the return to profit was 'testament to the fundamental strength of our business, our award-winning products, new technologies and operating efficiencies'.

The firm is also investing hundreds of millions of pounds to build a new range of electric cars, as demand grows for more environmentally-friendly vehicles.
